question.body: There really is a bone known as your “funny bone”

response.feedback: Incorrect. There is a bone in your arm called a humerus (not humerous). The sensation of hitting your “funny bone” occurs when you hit your ulnar nerve, which is close to the skin near your elbow.

question.body: Bones tissue is stagnant and not very active.

response.feedback: Incorrect. Bone tissue is constantly being remodeled. Bone is broken down and resynthesized. Approximately 20% of a young adult’s skeleton is completely remodeled every year.

question.body: There are bones in the human body that are floating bones and not attached to any other bones.

response.feedback: Correct. The hyoid bone is in the neck and is not attached to any other bones. It is attached to the larynx via ligaments.

question.body: A baby has more bones than an adult.

response.feedback: Correct. When a baby is born, many bones are still cartilage and have not fused together. A baby is born with approximately 305 bones while an adult has 206.
